description:
Brienomyrus brachyistius is a species of weakly electric fish belonging to the family Mormyridae, commonly known as elephant-nose fish. It is native to central Africa, specifically found in the Congo River basin.

Brienomyrus brachyistius is a small-sized fish, typically measuring around 10-15 centimeters in length. It has a distinctive elongated snout, which is a characteristic feature of the Mormyridae family. This snout is used to help the fish detect prey and navigate its environment.

As a weakly electric fish, Brienomyrus brachyistius generates a weak electric field around its body, which it uses for communication, navigation, and the detection of prey and predators. This electric field is produced by specialized electric organs located near the tail region of the fish.

The species is known to inhabit slow-moving, well-oxygenated rivers and streams, where it feeds primarily on small invertebrates and other aquatic organisms. Brienomyrus brachyistius plays an important role in the ecosystem, contributing to the overall biodiversity and food web dynamics of its native habitat.
